Small trees in supercritical random forests

Tao Lei Department of Mathematics and Statistics, McGill University, 805 Sherbrooke Street West, Montréal, Québec, H3A 0B9, Canada tao.lei@mail.mcgill.ca http://www.math.mcgill.ca/∼similar-to\simtlei/
(Date: October 5, 2017)
Abstract.

We study the scaling limit of random forest with prescribed degree sequence in the regime that the largest tree consists of all but a vanishing fraction of nodes. We give a description of the limit of the forest consisting of the small trees, by relating plane forest to marked cyclic forest and its corresponding lattice path.

Key words and phrases:
Random forests, continuum random trees, degree sequence, GHP convergence.
1991 Mathematics Subject Classification:
Primary: 60C05. Secondary: 05C05,05C80

1. Introduction

A plane tree is a finite rooted tree in which the children of each node are ordered. A plane forest is a finite sequence of plane trees.

Fix a plane tree T𝑇T and a plane forest F=(T1,…,Tc)𝐹subscript𝑇1…subscript𝑇𝑐F=(T_{1},\ldots,T_{c}). The node set of F𝐹F is v​(F)=⨆i≤cv​(Ti)𝑣𝐹subscriptsquare-union𝑖𝑐𝑣subscript𝑇𝑖v(F)=\bigsqcup_{i\leq c}v(T_{i}), where v​(Ti)𝑣subscript𝑇𝑖v(T_{i}) is the node set of Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} and where ⨆square-union\bigsqcup denotes disjoint union. For a node v∈v​(T)𝑣𝑣𝑇v\in v(T), by the degree of v𝑣v we mean the number of children of v𝑣v in T𝑇T. We denote this quantity kT​(v)subscript𝑘𝑇𝑣k_{T}(v). The degree of v∈v​(F)𝑣𝑣𝐹v\in v(F), denoted kF​(v)subscript𝑘𝐹𝑣k_{F}(v), is its degree in its tree, so if v∈v​(Ti)𝑣𝑣subscript𝑇𝑖v\in v(T_{i}) then kF​(v)=kTi​(v)subscript𝑘𝐹𝑣subscript𝑘subscript𝑇𝑖𝑣k_{F}(v)=k_{T_{i}}(v). For F𝐹F, we let F↓superscript𝐹↓F^{\downarrow} be the sequence of reordering {T1,⋯,Tc}subscript𝑇1⋯subscript𝑇𝑐\{T_{1},\cdots,T_{c}\} in decreasing order of number of nodes, breaking ties by the original order of appearance in F𝐹F.

For i≥0𝑖0i\geq 0 let si​(T)=#​{v∈v​(T):kT​(v)=i}superscript𝑠𝑖𝑇#conditional-set𝑣𝑣𝑇subscript𝑘𝑇𝑣𝑖s^{i}(T)=\#\{v\in v(T):k_{T}(v)=i\} and define si​(F)superscript𝑠𝑖𝐹s^{i}(F) accordingly, so si​(F)=∑j≤csi​(Tj)superscript𝑠𝑖𝐹subscript𝑗𝑐superscript𝑠𝑖subscript𝑇𝑗s^{i}(F)=\sum_{j\leq c}s^{i}(T_{j}). The degree sequences of T𝑇T and of F𝐹F are s​(T)=(si​(T),i≥0)𝑠𝑇superscript𝑠𝑖𝑇𝑖0s(T)=(s^{i}(T),i\geq 0) and s​(F)=(si​(F),i≥0)𝑠𝐹superscript𝑠𝑖𝐹𝑖0s(F)=(s^{i}(F),i\geq 0), respectively. Any sequence s=(si,i≥0)𝑠superscript𝑠𝑖𝑖0s=(s^{i},i\geq 0) of non-negative integers with ∑i≥0si<∞subscript𝑖0superscript𝑠𝑖\sum\limits_{i\geq 0}s^{i}<\infty and with ∑i≥0i​si<∑i≥0sisubscript𝑖0𝑖superscript𝑠𝑖subscript𝑖0superscript𝑠𝑖\sum\limits_{i\geq 0}is^{i}<\sum\limits_{i\geq 0}s^{i} is the degree sequence of some tree or forest. More precisely, writing c​(s):=∑i≥0(1−i)​si>0assign𝑐𝑠subscript𝑖01𝑖superscript𝑠𝑖0c(s):=\sum\limits_{i\geq 0}(1-i)s^{i}>0, then any forest with degree sequence s𝑠s consists of exactly c​(s)𝑐𝑠c(s) trees.

The goal of this paper is to study the asymptotic structure of large random forests with a given degree sequence, in the “supercritical”, finite variance regime. In this setting, the forest typically consists of a single, large tree containing all but a vanishing fraction of the nodes. The scaling limit of this tree is 𝒯𝒯{\mathcal{T}}, the Brownian Continuum Random Tree (CRT) introduced by Aldous in [2, 3, 4]. The remaining nodes form another random forest, which may be expected to have its own scaling limit (with an appropriate rescaling, which should be different from that of the large tree). The contributions of this paper confirm that the above picture is correct, and yield a pleasingly straightforward description, which we now provide, for the joint scaling limit of the large tree and the small trees.

Let B=(B​(t),t≥0)𝐵𝐵𝑡𝑡0B=(B(t),t\geq 0) be a linear Brownian motion. Theorem 1.1.

(σ​(pn)​Tn,1↓n1/2,σ​(pn)​F^ncn,n−|Tn,1↓|cn2)​→𝑑​(𝒯,ℱ,τ​(1σ))𝜎subscript𝑝𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑇↓𝑛1superscript𝑛12𝜎subscript𝑝𝑛subscript^𝐹𝑛subscript𝑐𝑛𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑇↓𝑛1subscriptsuperscript𝑐2𝑛𝑑→𝒯ℱ𝜏1𝜎\left(\frac{\sigma(p_{n})T^{\downarrow}_{n,1}}{n^{1/2}},\frac{\sigma(p_{n})\hat{F}_{n}}{c_{n}},\frac{n-|T^{\downarrow}_{n,1}|}{c^{2}_{n}}\right)\overset{d}{\rightarrow}\left({\mathcal{T}},\mathcal{F},\tau\left(\frac{1}{\sigma}\right)\right)

where the first coordinate of the joint convergence is in the GHP sense, the second coordinate is in the sense of coordinatewise GHP convergence, and 𝒯𝒯{\mathcal{T}} and ℱℱ\mathcal{F} are independent.

Remarks.
∙∙\bullet The condition that ∑i≥0sni=nsubscript𝑖0superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛𝑖𝑛\sum_{i\geq 0}s_{n}^{i}=n in Theorem 1.1 is for notational convenience; all proofs carry through with only cosmetic changes provided that |sn|=∑i≥0sni→∞subscript𝑠𝑛subscript𝑖0superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛𝑖→|s_{n}|=\sum_{i\geq 0}s_{n}^{i}\to\infty as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty, that |sn|−1⋅sn→p→⋅superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛1subscript𝑠𝑛𝑝|s_{n}|^{-1}\cdot s_{n}\to p in L2superscript𝐿2L^{2} and that cn=o​(|sn|1/2)subscript𝑐𝑛𝑜superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛12c_{n}=o(|s_{n}|^{1/2}).
∙∙\bullet Fix a critical, finite variance offspring distribution ν𝜈\nu, and let ℱnsubscriptℱ𝑛\mathcal{F}_{n} be a forest of cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n} independent Galton-Watson(ν)𝜈(\nu) trees with offspring distribution ν𝜈\nu, conditioned to have total progeny n𝑛n. It is not hard to check, as in [6], that with high probability the degree sequence of ℱnsubscriptℱ𝑛\mathcal{F}_{n} satisfies the conditions of Theorem 1.1, so the distributional convergence of the theorem also applies to ℱnsubscriptℱ𝑛\mathcal{F}_{n}. The convergence of the third coordinate, in the Galton-Watson setting, appears as Theorem 2.1.5 of [15], and provides a new proof and different perspective on that result; the convergence of the second coordinate strengthens and generalizes and removes a moment assumption from Theorem 1.7 of [7].

The field of scaling limit of large random structures is motivated by the seminal papers [2, 3, 4] by Aldous, where he introduced the concept of Brownian Continuum Random Tree and showed that critical Galton-Watson tree conditioned on its size has CRT as limiting object. To be more specific, our work here is a natural generalization of [6] where it is shown that under natural hypotheses on the degree sequences, after suitable normalization, uniformly random trees with given degree sequence converge to CRT as sizes of trees tend to infinity. Let n𝑛n be the number of nodes of the forest. In this paper we work on uniformly random forests where the number of trees is o​(n1/2)𝑜superscript𝑛12o(n^{1/2}); a previous paper [12] addressed the asymptotic behaviour of such forests in the regime where the number of trees is of order n1/2superscript𝑛12n^{1/2}.

Outline of the section

In the remainder of this section, we first briefly introduce the concepts required to understand the statement of Theorem 1.1 rigorously. In Section 1.2 we describe the key ingredients of the proof of our main theorem. In Section 1.3 we explain how to deduce Theorem 1.1 from the results of Section 1.2, and outline the remaining sections of the article.

1.1. Concepts

Real trees

We briefly recall the concepts of real trees and real trees coded by continuous functions, which are necessary for understanding the construction of ℱℱ\mathcal{F}. A more lengthy presentation about the probabilistic aspects of real trees can be found in [10, 11].

Definition 1.2.

A compact metric space (T,d)𝑇𝑑(T,d) is a real tree if the following hold for every a,b∈T𝑎𝑏𝑇a,b\in T:

(i) There is a unique isometric map fa,b:[0,d​(a,b)]→T:subscript𝑓𝑎𝑏→0𝑑𝑎𝑏𝑇f_{a,b}:[0,d(a,b)]\to T such that fa,b​(0)=asubscript𝑓𝑎𝑏0𝑎f_{a,b}(0)=a and fa,b​(d​(a,b))=bsubscript𝑓𝑎𝑏𝑑𝑎𝑏𝑏f_{a,b}(d(a,b))=b.

(ii) If q𝑞q is a continuous injective map from [0,1]01[0,1] into T𝑇T, such that q​(0)=a𝑞0𝑎q(0)=a and q​(1)=b𝑞1𝑏q(1)=b, we have q​([0,1])=fa,b​([0,d​(a,b)])𝑞01subscript𝑓𝑎𝑏0𝑑𝑎𝑏q([0,1])=f_{a,b}([0,d(a,b)]).

Now we show a way of constructing real trees from continuous functions. Let g:[0,∞)→[0,∞):𝑔→00g:[0,\infty)\rightarrow[0,\infty) be a continuous function with compact support and such that g​(0)=0𝑔00g(0)=0. For every s,t≥0𝑠𝑡0s,t\geq 0, let

dg∘​(s,t)=g​(s)+g​(t)−2​mg​(s,t)subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑔𝑠𝑡𝑔𝑠𝑔𝑡2subscript𝑚𝑔𝑠𝑡d^{\circ}_{g}(s,t)=g(s)+g(t)-2m_{g}(s,t)

where

mg​(s,t)=mins∧t≤r≤s∨t⁡g​(r).subscript𝑚𝑔𝑠𝑡subscript𝑠𝑡𝑟𝑠𝑡𝑔𝑟m_{g}(s,t)=\min\limits_{s\wedge t\leq r\leq s\vee t}g(r).

The function dg∘subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑔d^{\circ}_{g} is a pseudometric on [0,∞)0[0,\infty). Define an equivalence relation ∼similar-to\sim on [0,∞)0[0,\infty) by setting s∼tsimilar-to𝑠𝑡s\sim t iff dg∘​(s,t)=0subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑔𝑠𝑡0d^{\circ}_{g}(s,t)=0. Then let Tg=[0,∞)/∼T_{g}=[0,\infty)/\sim and let dgsubscript𝑑𝑔d_{g} be the induced distance on Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔T_{g}. Then (Tg,dg)subscript𝑇𝑔subscript𝑑𝑔(T_{g},d_{g}) is a real tree (see, e.g. Theorem 2.2 in [11]).

GHP convergence

Let (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d) and (X′,d′)superscript𝑋′superscript𝑑′(X^{\prime},d^{\prime}) be compact metric spaces. Then the Gromov-Hausdorff distance between (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d) and (X′,d′)superscript𝑋′superscript𝑑′(X^{\prime},d^{\prime}) is given by

where the infimum is taken over all isometric embeddings ϕ:X↪Z:italic-ϕ↪𝑋𝑍\phi:X\hookrightarrow Z and ϕ′:X′↪Z:superscriptitalic-ϕ′↪superscript𝑋′𝑍\phi^{\prime}:X^{\prime}\hookrightarrow Z into some common Polish metric space (Z,dZ)𝑍superscript𝑑𝑍(Z,d^{Z}) and dHZsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝐻𝑍d_{H}^{Z} denotes the Hausdorff distance between compact subsets of Z𝑍Z, that is,

where Aϵsuperscript𝐴italic-ϵA^{\epsilon} is the ϵ−limit-fromitalic-ϵ\epsilon-enlargement of A𝐴A:

Aϵ={z∈Z:infy∈AdZ​(y,z)<ϵ}.superscript𝐴italic-ϵconditional-set𝑧𝑍subscriptinfimum𝑦𝐴superscript𝑑𝑍𝑦𝑧italic-ϵA^{\epsilon}=\{z\in Z:\inf\limits_{y\in A}d^{Z}(y,z)<\epsilon\}.

Note that strictly speaking dG​Hsubscript𝑑𝐺𝐻d_{GH} is not a distance since different compact metric spaces can have GH distance zero.

A measured metric space 𝒳=(X,d,μ)𝒳𝑋𝑑𝜇\mathcal{X}=(X,d,\mu) is a metric space (X,d)𝑋𝑑(X,d) with a finite Borel measure μ𝜇\mu. Let 𝒳=(X,d,μ)𝒳𝑋𝑑𝜇\mathcal{X}=(X,d,\mu) and 𝒳′=(X′,d′,μ′)superscript𝒳′superscript𝑋′superscript𝑑′superscript𝜇′{\mathcal{X}}^{\prime}=(X^{\prime},d^{\prime},\mu^{\prime}) be two compact measured metric spaces, they are GHP-isometric if there exists an isometric one-to-one map Φ:X→X′:Φ→𝑋superscript𝑋′\Phi:X\rightarrow X^{\prime} such that Φ∗​μ=μ′subscriptΦ∗𝜇superscript𝜇′\Phi_{\ast}\mu=\mu^{\prime} where Φ∗​μsubscriptΦ∗𝜇\Phi_{\ast}\mu is the push forward of measure μ𝜇\mu to (X′,d′)superscript𝑋′superscript𝑑′(X^{\prime},d^{\prime}), that is, Φ∗​μ​(A)=μ​(Φ−1​(A))subscriptΦ∗𝜇𝐴𝜇superscriptΦ1𝐴\Phi_{\ast}\mu(A)=\mu(\Phi^{-1}(A)) for A∈ℬ​(X′)𝐴ℬsuperscript𝑋′A\in\mathcal{B}(X^{\prime}). In this case, call ΦΦ\Phi a GHP-isometry. Suppose both 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and 𝒳′superscript𝒳′\mathcal{X^{\prime}} are compact, then define the Gromov-Hausdorff-Prokhorov distance as:

dG​H​P​(𝒳,𝒳′)=infΦ,Φ′,Z(dHZ​(Φ​(X),Φ′​(X′))+dPZ​(Φ∗​μ,Φ∗′​μ′))subscript𝑑𝐺𝐻𝑃𝒳superscript𝒳′subscriptinfimumΦsuperscriptΦ′𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑑𝐻𝑍Φ𝑋superscriptΦ′superscript𝑋′superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑃𝑍subscriptΦ∗𝜇subscriptsuperscriptΦ′∗superscript𝜇′d_{GHP}(\mathcal{X},\mathcal{X^{\prime}})=\inf\limits_{\Phi,\Phi^{\prime},Z}(d_{H}^{Z}(\Phi(X),\Phi^{\prime}(X^{\prime}))+d_{P}^{Z}(\Phi_{\ast}\mu,\Phi^{\prime}_{\ast}\mu^{\prime}))

dPZ​(μ,ν)=inf{ϵ>0:μ​(A)≤ν​(Aϵ)+ϵ,ν​(A)≤μ​(Aϵ)+ϵ​ for any closed set ​A}.superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑃𝑍𝜇𝜈infimumconditional-setitalic-ϵ0formulae-sequence𝜇𝐴𝜈superscript𝐴italic-ϵitalic-ϵ𝜈𝐴𝜇superscript𝐴italic-ϵitalic-ϵ for any closed set 𝐴d_{P}^{Z}(\mu,\nu)=\inf\{\epsilon>0:\mu(A)\leq\nu(A^{\epsilon})+\epsilon,\nu(A)\leq\mu(A^{\epsilon})+\epsilon\mbox{ for any closed set }A\}.

Let 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} denote the set of GHP-isometry classes of compact measured metric spaces and we identify 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} with its GHP-isometry class.

Theorem 1.3 (Theorem 2.5 in [1]).

The function dG​H​Psubscript𝑑𝐺𝐻𝑃d_{GHP} defines a metric on 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} and the space (𝕂,dG​H​P)𝕂subscript𝑑𝐺𝐻𝑃(\mathbb{K},d_{GHP}) is a Polish metric space.

We next define coordinatewise GHP convergence of sequences of measured metric spaces. For 𝐗n=(𝒳n,j,j≥1),𝐗=(𝒳j,j≥1)formulae-sequencesubscript𝐗𝑛subscript𝒳𝑛𝑗𝑗1𝐗subscript𝒳𝑗𝑗1\mathbf{X}_{n}=(\mathcal{X}_{n,j},j\geq 1),\mathbf{X}=(\mathcal{X}_{j},j\geq 1) in 𝕂ℕsuperscript𝕂ℕ\mathbb{K}^{\mathbb{N}}, we say that 𝐗nsubscript𝐗𝑛\mathbf{X}_{n} converges to 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} in coordinatewise GHP sense if for any j∈ℕ𝑗ℕj\in\mathbb{N},

sup1≤l≤jdG​H​P​(𝒳n,l,𝒳l)→0​ as ​n→∞.→subscriptsupremum1𝑙𝑗subscript𝑑𝐺𝐻𝑃subscript𝒳𝑛𝑙subscript𝒳𝑙0 as 𝑛→\sup\limits_{1\leq l\leq j}d_{GHP}(\mathcal{X}_{n,l},\mathcal{X}_{l})\to 0\mbox{ as }n\to\infty.

Now to understand the statement of Theorem 1.1 in the rigorous way, we are viewing Tn,1↓subscriptsuperscript𝑇↓𝑛1T^{\downarrow}_{n,1} and each tree components of F^nsubscript^𝐹𝑛\hat{F}_{n} as measured metric space where the distance is rescaled graph distance and the measure is the uniform measure putting mass 1/n1𝑛1/n on each node of Tn,1↓subscriptsuperscript𝑇↓𝑛1T^{\downarrow}_{n,1} and F^nsubscript^𝐹𝑛\hat{F}_{n}.

1.3. Proof of Theorem 1.1

Now we are ready to give the proof of Theorem 1.1, assuming the results of Section 1.2.

Proof.

(σ​(pn)​Tn,1↓n1/2,(σ​(pn)​Tn,l↓cn,2≤l≤j),n−|Tn,1↓|cn2)​→𝑑​(𝒯,(𝒯1↓,⋯,𝒯j−1↓),τ​(1σ)).𝜎subscript𝑝𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑇↓𝑛1superscript𝑛12𝜎subscript𝑝𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑇↓𝑛𝑙subscript𝑐𝑛2𝑙𝑗𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑇↓𝑛1subscriptsuperscript𝑐2𝑛𝑑→𝒯subscriptsuperscript𝒯↓1⋯subscriptsuperscript𝒯↓𝑗1𝜏1𝜎\left(\frac{\sigma(p_{n})T^{\downarrow}_{n,1}}{n^{1/2}},\left(\frac{\sigma(p_{n})T^{\downarrow}_{n,l}}{c_{n}},2\leq l\leq j\right),\frac{n-|T^{\downarrow}_{n,1}|}{c^{2}_{n}}\right)\overset{d}{\to}\left({\mathcal{T}},({\mathcal{T}}^{\downarrow}_{1},\cdots,{\mathcal{T}}^{\downarrow}_{j-1}),\tau\left(\frac{1}{\sigma}\right)\right).

The convergence of the third coordinate is simply (1.2). This in particular implies that |Tn,1↓|n​→𝑝​1subscriptsuperscript𝑇↓𝑛1𝑛𝑝→1\frac{|T^{\downarrow}_{n,1}|}{n}\overset{p}{\to}1. With (1.4) and (1.5), we can also apply Theorem 1.6 to each Tn,l↓subscriptsuperscript𝑇↓𝑛𝑙T^{\downarrow}_{n,l} with l≥2𝑙2l\geq 2 and conclude that

Outline of the rest of the paper

In Section 2 we describe a combinatorial construction which associates a marked cyclic forest with the concatenation of a sequence of first passage bridges, followed by one lattice bridge. This construction is what links Theorem 1.4 with random forests. In Section 3 we give the proof of Theorem 1.4 and Corollary 1.5. Finally in Section 4 we prove (1.4) and (1.5) using martingale concentration inequalities.

2. Coding marked forests by lattice paths

We call a sequence of integers 𝐛=(b​(0),b​(1),…,b​(n))𝐛𝑏0𝑏1…𝑏𝑛\mathbf{b}=(b(0),b(1),\ldots,b(n)) a lattice bridge if

b​(0)=0,b​(n)=−1​ and ​∀0≤i≤n−1,b​(i+1)−b​(i)≥−1.formulae-sequenceformulae-sequence𝑏00𝑏𝑛1 and for-all0𝑖𝑛1𝑏𝑖1𝑏𝑖1b(0)=0,b(n)=-1\mbox{ and }\forall 0\leq i\leq n-1,~{}b(i+1)-b(i)\geq-1.

If 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} is a lattice bridge and mini⁡{i:b​(i)=−1}=nsubscript𝑖:𝑖𝑏𝑖1𝑛\min\limits_{i}\{i:b(i)=-1\}=n, then we call 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} a first passage bridge. Given a lattice bridge 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} and a positive integer k≤n𝑘𝑛k\leq n, we define a lattice bridge 𝐛(k)superscript𝐛𝑘\mathbf{b}^{(k)} as follows. First, for 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n, let b​(n+i)=b​(n)+b​(i)=−1+b​(i)𝑏𝑛𝑖𝑏𝑛𝑏𝑖1𝑏𝑖b(n+i)=b(n)+b(i)=-1+b(i). Then for 0≤i≤n0𝑖𝑛0\leq i\leq n, let 𝐛(k)​(i)=b​(k+i)−b​(k)superscript𝐛𝑘𝑖𝑏𝑘𝑖𝑏𝑘\mathbf{b}^{(k)}(i)=b(k+i)-b(k). Let [n]={1,⋯,n}delimited-[]𝑛1⋯𝑛[n]=\{1,\cdots,n\}. We have the following elementary lemma as a variant of the classical ballot theorem.

Lemma 2.1 (Lemma 6.1 in [16]).

Fix a lattice bridge 𝐛=(b​(i),0≤i≤n)𝐛𝑏𝑖0𝑖𝑛\mathbf{b}=(b(i),0\leq i\leq n), and let r=r​(𝐛)∈[n]𝑟𝑟𝐛delimited-[]𝑛r=r(\mathbf{b})\in[n] be minimal so that b​(r)=min⁡(b​(i),i≤n)𝑏𝑟𝑏𝑖𝑖𝑛b(r)=\min(b(i),i\leq n). Then 𝐛(r)superscript𝐛𝑟\mathbf{b}^{(r)} is a first passage bridge, and r𝑟r is the only such value in [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n].

Lemma 2.1 is illustrated by Figure 2.1(a) and Figure 2.1(b). In Figure 2.1(a) we have a lattice bridge 𝐛=(0,−1,−1,−2,−1,1,0,−1)𝐛01121101\mathbf{b}=(0,-1,-1,-2,-1,1,0,-1). The vertical dashed line shows the position of 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} attaining its minimum for the first time, hence the unique position for the cyclic shift to transform 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} to a first passage bridge, as claimed by Lemma 2.1. The resulting first lattice bridge, with steps 𝐛(3)superscript𝐛3\mathbf{b}^{(3)}, is shown in Figure 2.1(b).

A plane tree is a rooted tree T𝑇T in which the children of each node have a left-to-right order. Recall that for a plane tree T𝑇T and a node v∈v​(T)𝑣𝑣𝑇v\in v(T), we write kT​(v)subscript𝑘𝑇𝑣k_{T}(v) to denote the degree of v𝑣v in T𝑇T. We also write lex​(T)=(kT​(u1),…,kT​(u|T|))lex𝑇subscript𝑘𝑇subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑘𝑇subscript𝑢𝑇\mathrm{lex}(T)=(k_{T}(u_{1}),\ldots,k_{T}(u_{|T|})) where (ui,1≤i≤|T|)=(ui​(T),1≤i≤|T|)subscript𝑢𝑖1𝑖𝑇subscript𝑢𝑖𝑇1𝑖𝑇(u_{i},1\leq i\leq|T|)=(u_{i}(T),1\leq i\leq|T|) are nodes of T𝑇T listed in lexicographic order.

For any sequence 𝐜=(c1,⋯,cn)∈ℝn𝐜subscript𝑐1⋯subscript𝑐𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛\mathbf{c}=(c_{1},\cdots,c_{n})\in\mathbb{R}^{n}, we write W𝐜​(j)=∑i=1j(ci−1)subscript𝑊𝐜𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑗subscript𝑐𝑖1W_{\mathbf{c}}(j)=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{j}(c_{i}-1) for j∈[n]𝑗delimited-[]𝑛j\in[n], let W𝐜​(0)=0subscript𝑊𝐜00W_{\mathbf{c}}(0)=0 and make W𝐜subscript𝑊𝐜W_{\mathbf{c}} a continuous function on [0,n]0𝑛[0,n] by linear interpolation. A classical bijection between plane trees and first passage bridges associates to a tree T𝑇T its depth-first walk (Wlex​(T)​(i),0≤i≤n)subscript𝑊lex𝑇𝑖0𝑖𝑛(W_{\mathrm{lex}(T)}(i),0\leq i\leq n), see, e.g. Chapter 6 of [16]. We build on this bijection below.

For a plane tree T𝑇T and v∈v​(T)𝑣𝑣𝑇v\in v(T), we call the pair (T,v)𝑇𝑣(T,v) a marked tree and call v𝑣v the mark. The bijection between first passage bridges and plane trees also leads to a bijection between lattice bridges and marked trees. This bijection, depicted in Figure 2.1, is specified as follows. For a lattice bridge 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b}, let r=r​(𝐛)𝑟𝑟𝐛r=r(\mathbf{b}) as in Lemma 2.1, let 𝐛′=𝐛(r)superscript𝐛′superscript𝐛𝑟\mathbf{b}^{\prime}=\mathbf{b}^{(r)} be the first passage bridge corresponding to 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b}, and let T𝑇T be the plane tree with depth-first walk 𝐛′superscript𝐛′\mathbf{b}^{\prime}. Then the marked node is v=u|T|−r+1​(T)𝑣subscript𝑢𝑇𝑟1𝑇v=u_{|T|-r+1}(T), the (|T|−r+1)𝑇𝑟1(|T|-r+1)’st node of T𝑇T in lexicographic order. The mark v𝑣v is denoted by a red square in Figure 2.1.

A marked forest is a pair (F,v)𝐹𝑣(F,v) where F𝐹F is a plane forest and v∈v​(F)𝑣𝑣𝐹v\in v(F). We refer v𝑣v as the mark of (F,v)𝐹𝑣(F,v). A marked cyclic forest is a marked forest with its mark in its last tree; the name is because we can equivalently view such a forest as having its trees arranged around a cycle.

Fix an integer sequence W=(Wi:0≤i≤n)W=(W_{i}:0\leq i\leq n) with W0=0,Wn=−kformulae-sequencesubscript𝑊00subscript𝑊𝑛𝑘W_{0}=0,W_{n}=-k, and Wi−Wi−1≥−1subscript𝑊𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖11W_{i}-W_{i-1}\geq-1 for all 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n. The bijections described above allow us to view W𝑊W as a marked cyclic forest (F,v)=(F​(W),v​(W))𝐹𝑣𝐹𝑊𝑣𝑊(F,v)=(F(W),v(W)) consisting of k−1𝑘1k-1 trees and one marked tree, as follows. Then (F​(W),v​(W))=((T1,…,Tk),v)𝐹𝑊𝑣𝑊subscript𝑇1…subscript𝑇𝑘𝑣(F(W),v(W))=((T_{1},\ldots,T_{k}),v). This bijection is illustrated in Figure 2.3 and Figure 2.3. In Figure 2.3 the whole sequence is decomposed into three segments (divided by vertical dashed lines). The last part is a lattice bridge, hence corresponds to a marked tree (T3,v)subscript𝑇3𝑣(T_{3},v) and the node v𝑣v is again depicted by a square mark. These trees are shown in Figure 2.3.

Given a degree sequence s=(s(i),i≥0)𝑠superscript𝑠𝑖𝑖0s=(s^{(i)},i\geq 0) with ∑i≥0si=nsubscript𝑖0superscript𝑠𝑖𝑛\sum_{i\geq 0}s^{i}=n, recall from Section 1.2 that d​(s)∈ℤ≥0n𝑑𝑠superscriptsubscriptℤabsent0𝑛d(s)\in\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}^{n} is the vector whose entries are weakly increasing and with s(i)superscript𝑠𝑖s^{(i)} entries equal to i𝑖i, for each i≥0𝑖0i\geq 0. Lemma 2.2.

In particular, we have the following corollary.

Corollary 2.3.

We will also need the following easy fact connecting linear forests with marked cyclic forests.

Lemma 2.4.

Fix a degree sequence s=(s(i),i≥0)𝑠superscript𝑠𝑖𝑖0s=(s^{(i)},i\geq 0), and let F𝐹F be a uniformly random linear forest with degree sequence s𝑠s, and let (F∗,v)superscript𝐹𝑣(F^{*},v) be the marked cyclic forest obtained from F𝐹F by marking a uniformly random node and applying the requisite cyclic shift of the trees of F𝐹F. Then (F∗,v)superscript𝐹𝑣(F^{*},v) is a uniformly random element of MCF​(s)MCF𝑠\mathrm{MCF}(s).

Proof.

Let F​(s)F𝑠\mathrm{F}(s) be the set of all plane forests with degree sequence s𝑠s. The operation of marking a node induces an n𝑛n-to-c​(s)𝑐𝑠c(s) map from F​(s)F𝑠\mathrm{F}(s) to MCF​(s)MCF𝑠\mathrm{MCF}(s), from which the lemma is immediate. ∎

The preceding lemma allows us to relate the random forest Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n} from Theorem 1.1 with the lattice path Sn=(Sn,k,0≤k≤n)subscript𝑆𝑛subscript𝑆𝑛𝑘0𝑘𝑛S_{n}=(S_{n,k},0\leq k\leq n) from Theorem 1.4. Let (Fn∗,vn)=((Tn,k,1≤k≤cn),vn)superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛subscript𝑇𝑛𝑘1𝑘subscript𝑐𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛(F_{n}^{*},v_{n})=((T_{n,k},1\leq k\leq c_{n}),v_{n}) be obtained from Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n} by marking a uniformly random node and applying the requisite cyclic shift of the trees of Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n}. Then we may couple Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n} and Snsubscript𝑆𝑛S_{n} so that Sn=(Sn,j,0≤j≤n)subscript𝑆𝑛subscript𝑆𝑛𝑗0𝑗𝑛S_{n}=(S_{n,j},0\leq j\leq n) is the coding walk of (Fn∗,vn)superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛(F_{n}^{*},v_{n}). We work with such a coupling for the remainder of the paper.

To prove (3.2), we need the following result concerning dilation. Recall (or see, e.g., [5]) that given real random variables U,V𝑈𝑉U,V, we say U𝑈U is a dilation of V𝑉V if there exist random variables U^,V^^𝑈^𝑉\hat{U},\hat{V} such that

U^​=𝑑​U,V^​=𝑑​V​ and ​𝐄​[U^|V^]=V^.^𝑈𝑑𝑈^𝑉𝑑𝑉 and 𝐄delimited-[]conditional^𝑈^𝑉^𝑉\hat{U}\overset{d}{=}U,~{}\hat{V}\overset{d}{=}V\mbox{ and }{\mathbf{E}}\left[\hat{U}|\hat{V}\right]=\hat{V}.
Proposition 3.2 (Proposition 20.6 in [5]).

Recall that in Section 1 we let τ(x)=inf(t:B(t)≤−x)\tau(x)=\inf(t:B(t)\leq-x) for x≥0𝑥0x\geq 0. Corollary 3.3.

Given the assumptions in Theorem 1.1, we have

τncn2​→𝑑​τ​(1σ),subscript𝜏𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑐2𝑛𝑑→𝜏1𝜎\frac{\tau_{n}}{c^{2}_{n}}\overset{d}{\to}\tau(\frac{1}{\sigma}), (3.11)

The corollary above in fact tells us something about the size of the largest tree Tn,1↓subscriptsuperscript𝑇↓𝑛1T^{\downarrow}_{n,1}.

Corollary 3.4.

For a marked cyclic forest (F,v)𝐹𝑣(F,v), let M​T​(F,v)𝑀𝑇𝐹𝑣MT(F,v) denoted the marked tree, i.e. the tree of F𝐹F containing v𝑣v. Then

𝐏​{M​T​(Fn∗,vn)=Tn,1↓}→1→𝐏𝑀𝑇superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑇↓𝑛11{\mathbf{P}}\left\{MT(F_{n}^{*},v_{n})=T^{\downarrow}_{n,1}\right\}\to 1

as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty.

Proof.

It is clear that

𝐏​{M​T​(Fn∗,vn)≠Tn,1↓}𝐏𝑀𝑇superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑇↓𝑛1\displaystyle{\mathbf{P}}\left\{MT(F_{n}^{*},v_{n})\neq T^{\downarrow}_{n,1}\right\} ≤\displaystyle\leq 𝐏​{|M​T​(Fn∗,vn)|<n/2}𝐏𝑀𝑇superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛𝑛2\displaystyle{\mathbf{P}}\left\{|MT(F_{n}^{*},v_{n})|<n/2\right\}
=\displaystyle= 𝐏​{τn>n/2}=𝐏​{τncn2>n2​cn2}→0𝐏subscript𝜏𝑛𝑛2𝐏subscript𝜏𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑐2𝑛𝑛2subscriptsuperscript𝑐2𝑛→0\displaystyle{\mathbf{P}}\left\{\tau_{n}>n/2\right\}={\mathbf{P}}\left\{\frac{\tau_{n}}{c^{2}_{n}}>\frac{n}{2c^{2}_{n}}\right\}\to 0

where in the last line, the first equation is by Lemma 2.4 and the final convergence is by Corollary 3.3 and the assumption cn2=o​(n)subscriptsuperscript𝑐2𝑛𝑜𝑛c^{2}_{n}=o(n). ∎

Now we are ready to prove Corollary 1.5.

Proof of Corollary 1.5.

As noted, it suffices to prove (1.2) and (1.3). Corollary 3.3 and Corollary 3.4 together imply (1.2).

For (1.3), first note that by Lemma 2.2, the process Sn=(Sn,k,0≤k≤n)subscript𝑆𝑛subscript𝑆𝑛𝑘0𝑘𝑛S_{n}=(S_{n,k},0\leq k\leq n) has the same law as the coding walk W​(Fn)𝑊subscript𝐹𝑛W(F_{n}) of Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n}. Applying Corollary 3.4 then yields that the law of (|Tn,2↓|,…,|Tn,j↓|)superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛2↓…superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝑗↓(|T_{n,2}^{\downarrow}|,\ldots,|T_{n,j}^{\downarrow}|) is asymptotically equivalent to the law of (g1n−d1n,…,gj−1n−dj−1n)subscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑛1subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑛1…subscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑛𝑗1subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑛𝑗1(g^{n}_{1}-d^{n}_{1},\ldots,g^{n}_{j-1}-d^{n}_{j-1}), the first j−1𝑗1j-1 ranked excursion lengths of Snsubscript𝑆𝑛S_{n} above its running minimum before time τnsubscript𝜏𝑛\tau_{n}. Using this equivalence, (1.3) now follows from Theorem 1.4 by the Portmanteau Theorem ([14], Theorem 12.6), since the vector (g1−d1,…,gj−1−dj−1)subscript𝑔1subscript𝑑1…subscript𝑔𝑗1subscript𝑑𝑗1(g_{1}-d_{1},\ldots,g_{j-1}-d_{j-1}) has a density. ∎

4. Empirical degree sequences of trees

In this section we aim to prove (1.4) and (1.5).

For i≥0𝑖0i\geq 0 and x≤n𝑥𝑛x\leq n, let

where we use (4.5) in the second line.

Let Ln=∑j≤M​cn2Cn,j2​𝟙Cn,j≥tsubscript𝐿𝑛subscript𝑗𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑛2subscriptsuperscript𝐶2𝑛𝑗subscript1subscript𝐶𝑛𝑗𝑡L_{n}=\sum_{j\leq Mc_{n}^{2}}C^{2}_{n,j}\mathbbm{1}_{C_{n,j}\geq t}. so
